trans-unit.source: Get Started with Docker and Compose on an Azure virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Get Started with Docker and Compose on an Azure virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Quick introduction to working with Compose and Docker on Azure
trans-unit.target: Quick introduction to working with Compose and Docker on Azure

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to get started using Docker and <linkText>Compose</linkText><title></title> to define and run a complex application on a Linux virtual machine in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to get started using Docker and <linkText>Compose</linkText><title></title> to define and run a complex application on a Linux virtual machine in Azure.

trans-unit.source: With Compose (the successor to Fig), you use a simple text file to define an application consisting of multiple Docker containers.
trans-unit.target: With Compose (the successor to Fig), you use a simple text file to define an application consisting of multiple Docker containers.

trans-unit.source: Then you spin up your application in a single command which does everything to get it running on the VM.
trans-unit.target: Then you spin up your application in a single command which does everything to get it running on the VM.

trans-unit.source: As an example, this article shows you how to quickly set up a WordPress blog with a backend MariaDB SQL database, but you can also use Compose to set up more complex applications.
trans-unit.target: As an example, this article shows you how to quickly set up a WordPress blog with a backend MariaDB SQL database, but you can also use Compose to set up more complex applications.

trans-unit.source: If you're new to Docker and containers, see the <linkText>Docker high level whiteboard</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you're new to Docker and containers, see the <linkText>Docker high level whiteboard</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can use a variety of Azure procedures and available images in the Azure Markeplace to create a Linux VM and set it up as a Docker host.
trans-unit.target: You can use a variety of Azure procedures and available images in the Azure Markeplace to create a Linux VM and set it up as a Docker host.

trans-unit.source: For example, see <linkText>Using the Docker VM Extension from the Azure Command-Line Interface</linkText><title></title> for a quick procedure to create an Ubuntu VM with the Docker VM extension.
trans-unit.target: For example, see <linkText>Using the Docker VM Extension from the Azure Command-Line Interface</linkText><title></title> for a quick procedure to create an Ubuntu VM with the Docker VM extension.

trans-unit.source: When you use the Docker VM extension, your VM is automatically set up as a Docker host.
trans-unit.target: When you use the Docker VM extension, your VM is automatically set up as a Docker host.

trans-unit.source: The example in that article shows you how to use the the <linkText>Azure command-line interface for Mac, Linux, and Windows</linkText><title></title> (the Azure CLI) in Service Management mode to create the VM.
trans-unit.target: The example in that article shows you how to use the the <linkText>Azure command-line interface for Mac, Linux, and Windows</linkText><title></title> (the Azure CLI) in Service Management mode to create the VM.

trans-unit.source: After the Linux VM is running with Docker, connect to it from your client computer using SSH.
trans-unit.target: After the Linux VM is running with Docker, connect to it from your client computer using SSH.

trans-unit.source: If you need to, install <linkText>Compose</linkText><title></title> by running the following two commands.
trans-unit.target: If you need to, install <linkText>Compose</linkText><title></title> by running the following two commands.

trans-unit.source: If you used the Docker VM extension to create your VM, Compose is already installed for you.
trans-unit.target: If you used the Docker VM extension to create your VM, Compose is already installed for you.

trans-unit.source: Skip these commands and go to Step 3.
trans-unit.target: Skip these commands and go to Step 3.

trans-unit.source: You only need to install Compose if you installed Docker on the VM yourself.
trans-unit.target: You only need to install Compose if you installed Docker on the VM yourself.

trans-unit.source: If you get a "Permission denied" error, your /usr/local/bin directory on the VM probably isn't writable and you'll need to install Compose as the superuser.
trans-unit.target: If you get a "Permission denied" error, your /usr/local/bin directory on the VM probably isn't writable and you'll need to install Compose as the superuser.

trans-unit.source: Run sudo -i, then the two commands above, then exit.
trans-unit.target: Run sudo -i, then the two commands above, then exit.

trans-unit.source: To test your installation of Compose, run the following command.
trans-unit.target: To test your installation of Compose, run the following command.

trans-unit.source: You will see output similar to
trans-unit.target: You will see output similar to

trans-unit.source: Next you'll create a docker-compose.yml file, which is just a text configuration file, to define the Docker containers to run on the VM.
trans-unit.target: Next you'll create a docker-compose.yml file, which is just a text configuration file, to define the Docker containers to run on the VM.

trans-unit.source: The file specifies the image to run on each container (or it could be a build from a Dockerfile), necessary environment variables and dependencies, ports, links between containers, and so on.
trans-unit.target: The file specifies the image to run on each container (or it could be a build from a Dockerfile), necessary environment variables and dependencies, ports, links between containers, and so on.

trans-unit.source: For details on yml file syntax, see <linkText>docker-compose.yml reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For details on yml file syntax, see <linkText>docker-compose.yml reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Create a working directory on your VM, and use your favorite text editor to create docker-compose.yml.
trans-unit.target: Create a working directory on your VM, and use your favorite text editor to create docker-compose.yml.

trans-unit.source: To try a simple example, copy the following text to the file.
trans-unit.target: To try a simple example, copy the following text to the file.

trans-unit.source: This configuration uses images from the <linkText>DockerHub Registry</linkText><title></title> to install WordPress (the open source blogging and content management system) and a linked backend MariaDB SQL database.
trans-unit.target: This configuration uses images from the <linkText>DockerHub Registry</linkText><title></title> to install WordPress (the open source blogging and content management system) and a linked backend MariaDB SQL database.

trans-unit.source: ``` wordpress: image: wordpress links: - db:mysql ports: - 8080:80
trans-unit.target: ``` wordpress: image: wordpress links: - db:mysql ports: - 8080:80

trans-unit.source: db: image: mariadb environment: MYSQLROOTPASSWORD:
trans-unit.target: db: image: mariadb environment: MYSQLROOTPASSWORD:

trans-unit.source: $ docker-compose up -d
trans-unit.target: $ docker-compose up -d

trans-unit.source: Creating wordpressdb1... Creating wordpresswordpress1...
trans-unit.target: Creating wordpressdb1... Creating wordpresswordpress1...

trans-unit.source: wordpressdb1 /docker- Up 3306/tcp entrypoint.sh mysqld wordpresswordpr /entrypoint.sh Up 0.0.0.0:8080->80 ess1 apache2-for ... /tcp
trans-unit.target: wordpressdb1 /docker- Up 3306/tcp entrypoint.sh mysqld wordpresswordpr /entrypoint.sh Up 0.0.0.0:8080->80 ess1 apache2-for ... /tcp

trans-unit.source: $ azure vm endpoint create <machine-name> 80 8080
trans-unit.target: $ azure vm endpoint create <machine-name> 80 8080

trans-unit.source: You should now see the WordPress start screen, where you can complete the installation and get started with the application.
trans-unit.target: You should now see the WordPress start screen, where you can complete the installation and get started with the application.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>WordPress start screen</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>WordPress start screen</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Check out the <linkText>Compose CLI reference</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>user guide</linkText><title></title> for more examples of building and deploying multi-container apps.
trans-unit.target: Check out the <linkText>Compose CLI reference</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>user guide</linkText><title></title> for more examples of building and deploying multi-container apps.

trans-unit.source: Use an Azure Resource Manager template, either your own or one contributed from the <linkText>community</linkText><title></title>, to deploy an Azure VM with Docker and an application set up with Compose.
trans-unit.target: Use an Azure Resource Manager template, either your own or one contributed from the <linkText>community</linkText><title></title>, to deploy an Azure VM with Docker and an application set up with Compose.

trans-unit.source: For example, the <linkText>Deploy a WordPress blog with Docker</linkText><title></title> template uses Docker and Compose to quickly deploy WordPress with a MySQL backend on an Ubuntu VM.
trans-unit.target: For example, the <linkText>Deploy a WordPress blog with Docker</linkText><title></title> template uses Docker and Compose to quickly deploy WordPress with a MySQL backend on an Ubuntu VM.

trans-unit.source: Try integrating Docker Compose with a <linkText>Docker Swarm</linkText><title></title> cluster.
trans-unit.target: Try integrating Docker Compose with a <linkText>Docker Swarm</linkText><title></title> cluster.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Docker Compose/Swarm integration</linkText><title></title> for scenarios.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Docker Compose/Swarm integration</linkText><title></title> for scenarios.
